questions.text:
Assertion (A): Proton beam therapy is used for chordoma

Reason (R): Chordoma arises from notochordal remnants
questions.solution:
Ans. B. If both A and R are correct, and R is not the correct explanation of A

 

Explanations:

 

Proton beam therapy is an effective treatment option for chordoma, which is a rare and slow-growing tumor that often occurs in the skull base and spine. Chordomas are often difficult to treat due to their location and tendency to recur, and traditional radiation therapy can cause significant damage to surrounding healthy tissues.

 

Proton therapy offers a more precise form of radiation that delivers a higher dose to the tumor while minimizing exposure to nearby organs and tissues called as Bragg’s peak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proton beam therapy is utilized for the treatment of chordoma because of its precision in delivering high radiation doses to the tumor, with minimal exposure to surrounding healthy tissues. This advanced treatment approach is beneficial due to the complex location of chordomas, which originate from notochordal remnants. While the origin of chordoma provides context for its occurrence, it does not explain the specific use of proton beam therapy over other treatment modalities.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 734

questions.text: A patient is suffering from carcinoma endometrium and is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation to the whole pelvis. Which of the following organs is most radiosensitive in the pelvic regions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ovary

 

Option A:

 

Ovary: The ovaries are highly radiosensitive due to their rapidly dividing germ cells. In the context of pelvic irradiation, the ovaries are the most vulnerable organ, which can lead to premature ovarian failure and infertility, especially in premenopausal women

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Vagina: While the vagina is part of the pelvic radiation field, it is less sensitive to radiation compared to the ovaries. Radiation-induced vaginal changes can include atrophy, stenosis, and dryness, but these are often late effects and less severe than ovarian damage. 

 

Option C. Bladder: The bladder has a moderate level of radiosensitivity. Acute effects of radiation to the bladder can include cystitis, characterized by urgency, frequency, and dysuria. Chronic effects can lead to fibrosis and reduced bladder capacity, but these are generally less frequent than ovarian damage.

 

Option D. Rectum: Similar to the bladder, the rectum has a moderate level of radiosensitivity. Acute radiation effects can cause proctitis with symptoms like rectal bleeding, diarrhea, and discomfort. Chronic effects may include fibrosis and strictures, but the ovaries remain the most sensitive due to the presence of rapidly dividing cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of pelvic irradiation for carcinoma of the endometrium, the ovaries are the most radiosensitive organ due to their high proliferation rate of germ cells, making them susceptible to radiation-induced damage. This can have significant implications for fertility and hormonal function in premenopausal women.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 698

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of head and neck cancer treated with radiation therapy presents with persistent pain and exposed bone in the mandible, unresponsive to conservative management for several months. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Osteoradionecrosis

 

Option D:

 

Osteoradionecrosis is a severe late effect of radiation therapy that involves the death of bone tissue due to a compromised blood supply after radiation. It can manifest months to years post-treatment, with the jawbone being a common site. Patients present with pain, non-healing wounds, and bone exposure. Management can be challenging and often requires a multidisciplinary approach.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common early side effect of radiation therapy, particularly when the abdominal or pelvic regions are involved. It usually occurs within hours to days after treatment begins and can often be managed with antiemetic medications.

 

Option B. Erythema: Erythema refers to the reddening of the skin that can occur after radiation exposure. It is also an early side effect, similar to sunburn, and can appear within days to weeks of starting therapy. The severity of erythema varies and is typically self-limited.

 

Option C. Anemia: Anemia can be both an early or late side effect of radiation therapy. Early on, it may be due to acute damage to the bone marrow, leading to decreased production of red blood cells. Late effects can be due to chronic bone marrow insufficiency or fibrosis, resulting in sustained reduced red blood cell production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoradionecrosis is a significant late complication characterized by the death of bone tissue due to its reduced blood supply following radiation, leading to persistent pain, non-healing wounds, and bone exposure.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 464

questions.text: A 35-year-old male who was working at a nuclear power plant that had a radiation leak accident. He was exposed to a high dose of radiation and was taken to the hospital immediately. On examination, he had severe nausea and vomiting, along with abdominal pain and diarrhea. He also complained of a headache, dizziness, and fatigue. His skin was red and inflamed, and he had blisters on his hands and feet. His initial blood tests showed a low white blood cell count, indicating bone marrow suppression. His platelet count was also low, and he had anemia. Threshold radiation dose for hematological syndrome is? Intermediate
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2 Gy

 

Explanation:

 

Acute radiation syndrome (ARS) is a medical condition that occurs after exposure to high doses of ionizing radiation over a short period. The severity of ARS depends on the amount of radiation absorbed by the body and the duration of exposure.

 

Threshold radiation dose for acute radiation syndromes:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The threshold radiation dose for hematological syndrome in acute radiation syndrome is 2 Gy, characterized by bone marrow suppression leading to a decreased count of blood cells, nausea, and vomiting. This dose is the lowest among the thresholds for major radiation syndromes and is sufficient to cause the initial symptoms of acute radiation syndrome.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition,

questions.text: A patient with a deep-seated brain tumor is scheduled for radiation therapy. The treatment plan includes using a type of radiation that delivers the highest energy dose at the end of its path, minimizing exposure to the surrounding healthy brain tissue. This technique is advantageous for treating the tumor while preserving as much healthy tissue as possible. Which type of radiation achieves this?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Protons

 

Option C.

 

Bragg's peak effect is seen in proton radiation therapy.

 

Proton therapy exhibits the Bragg's peak effect, wherein protons release most of their energy at a specific depth, corresponding to the tumor location, which is an ideal characteristic for targeting tumors and sparing healthy tissue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Xrays. X-rays deliver a dose along their entire path through the body, which includes both the tumor and healthy tissue, without a distinct peak where the maximum dose is delivered.

 

Option B. Neutrons. Neutron therapy also delivers energy along its path but lacks the precision of the Bragg's peak, leading to more widespread tissue exposure.

 

Option D. Electrons. Electron beams deliver energy relatively superficially and are not used for deep-seated tumors due to the lack of depth penetration compared to proton therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bragg's peak effect is characteristic of proton radiation therapy, where protons deliver the highest dose of radiation at the end of their path, at the tumor site, sparing the surrounding healthy tissues. This property makes proton therapy an excellent choice for treating localized tumors where precision is paramount.

 

 

Depth of penetration →

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: While planning radiotherapy for a variety of cancers, a radiation oncologist must choose the most appropriate and commonly used form of radiation. This form is preferred for its deep tissue penetration and the ability to conform to complex tumor shapes, making it the cornerstone of radiotherapy practices. Which of the following types of radiation is most commonly utilized in standard radiotherapy treatments?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. X-rays

 

Option A:

 

One-liners in RT:

 

MC method of Radiotherapy – X rays

 

Proton Beam – BRAGG’s PEAK: Used in Deep seated Brain Tumor; skull base Chordoma

 

Electron Beam –Used in Cutaneous T-cell Lymphoma (Mycosis Fungoides); Eyelids & Lips tumors; Intra-operative RT

 

X-rays are the most commonly used form of radiation in radiotherapy due to their deep tissue penetration and the ability to be shaped to conform to the three-dimensional contour of the tumor, minimizing damage to the surrounding healthy tissue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Beta rays have limited penetration depth and are less commonly used in standard radiotherapy, more often utilized in radioisotope therapy.

 

Option C. Alpha particles have very low penetration and are not used for external radiotherapy due to their inability to reach internal targets without significant damage to superficial tissues.

 

Option D. Electron beams are used in radiotherapy but are more commonly reserved for treating superficial tumors due to their limited penetration depth compared to X-rays.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-rays are the most commonly used radiation type in radiotherapy because of their ability to penetrate deeply and be conformed to the shape of the tumor, which makes them versatile for treating a wide range of malignancies with precision.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

Better than teletherapy for Large & bulky tumor
Deliver higher dose of radiation to tumor

questions.text: A medical student is reviewing the advantages of different radiation therapy techniques. Brachytherapy is being compared to teletherapy, particularly in the context of its effectiveness and tissue impact. Which of the following statements regarding brachytherapy is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Better than teletherapy for large & bulky tumor

 

Option B:

 

Brachytherapy is generally not considered better than teletherapy for treating large and bulky tumors due to its limited penetration and the need for the radioactive source to be close to the target tissue, which may not be feasible or effective for larger tumor volumes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. More effective in carcinoma cervix. Brachytherapy is highly effective in carcinoma of the cervix due to its ability to deliver high radiation doses directly to the tumor while minimizing exposure to the surrounding normal tissues.

 

Option C. Deliver higher dose of radiation to tumor. Brachytherapy allows for the delivery of a higher radiation dose directly to the tumor site, which is more effective for local control of small and well-defined tumors.

 

Option D. Less damage to normal tissue Brachytherapy minimizes damage to normal tissues adjacent to the tumor due to the rapid fall-off of radiation dose with distance from the radiation source, in accordance with the inverse square law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brachytherapy is not typically preferred over teletherapy for the treatment of large and bulky tumors. Instead, it is advantageous for delivering higher doses of radiation to smaller, well-defined tumors with minimal impact on surrounding normal tissues, making it a suitable option for conditions such as cervical carcinoma.

 

Types of RT:

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 700

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with early-stage breast cancer is being considered for localized radiation therapy following a lumpectomy. The radiation oncologist discusses employing a technique that involves the insertion of a radioactive source directly into the treatment site. “Remote after-loading” is employed with reference to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brachytherapy

 

Option D:

 

Remote after-loading is a technique used in brachytherapy where a machine delivers a radioactive source to the treatment site through a series of tubes or catheters.

 

Brachytherapy is a form of radiation treatment where a radioactive source is placed inside or next to the area requiring treatment.

Remote after-loading is a method used in brachytherapy to safely and accurately deliver radiation by temporarily placing radioactive sources in the body, minimizing radiation exposure to healthcare workers

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. External Beam Radiation Therapy (EBRT) This is a common method of delivering radiation therapy from outside the body, using a linear accelerator to target the tumor. It's often used for various types of cancers and can be delivered to any part of the body. It does not use a remote after-loading technique; instead, the radiation is delivered through the skin to the tumor site.

 

Option B. Proton Beam Therapy Proton therapy is a type of external beam radiation treatment that uses protons instead of X-rays. It allows for more precise targeting of the tumor with less damage to surrounding healthy tissues. It also doesn’t involve remote after-loading; the protons are generated in a cyclotron or synchrotron and delivered through a nozzle to the patient.

 

Option C. Nuclear Scintigraphy Nuclear scintigraphy, also known as a nuclear medicine scan, is a diagnostic imaging technique using radioactive substances to visualize organs and assess their function. It is not a treatment method and does not involve remote after-loading.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brachytherapy with remote after-loading is a technique used to deliver radiation internally, directly at the cancer site, which ensures higher precision in radiation delivery with minimal exposure to healthcare personnel and surrounding healthy tissues. This method is particularly useful in the treatment of localized cancers such as breast cancer post-lumpectomy.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 690

choices.text: Dose of radiation at a point is inversely proportional to the square of its distance from the source
Small vessels are resistant to radiation
Rectal and bladder mucosa are resistant to radiation

questions.text: A female patient with a confirmed diagnosis of stage 2B cervical cancer is undergoing a course of radiotherapy. In planning and delivering this treatment, which of the following principles is paramount in order to maximize therapeutic efficacy and minimize collateral tissue damage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dose of radiation at a point is inversely proportional to the square of its distance from the source

 

Option A:

 

True. The inverse square law is a fundamental concept in radiation physics that states the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This principle is critical for ensuring that the correct dose of radiation reaches the target tissue while minimizing exposure to surrounding healthy tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. False. Small vessels, like all living tissues, are susceptible to radiation damage, which can lead to long-term complications, including fibrosis and necrosis within irradiated tissues.

 

Option C. False. Actively dividing cells are more susceptible to radiation because they are more likely to undergo mitotic death. Radiotherapy does not spare these cells; in fact, it targets them due to their high mitotic rate.

 

Option D. False. The mucosa of the rectum and bladder are sensitive to radiation, and care must be taken to protect these structures during treatment planning and delivery to avoid severe side effects and complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inverse square law is a key principle in radiation therapy and it is important to understand the importance of distance from the radiation source in determining tissue dose.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A physicist is consulting on the treatment planning for a patient who requires high precision radiation therapy. Which of the following particles is recognized for having the highest ionization potential and is thus capable of causing the most significant biological damage per unit path length when used in radiation treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Helium ion

 

Option C:

 

Helium ions, or alpha particles, have a high ionization potential due to their larger mass and charge compared to electrons and protons, leading to dense ionization along their path. They can cause significant cellular damage, but their use is limited due to their high potential for collateral damage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Electrons have significant ionizing potential and are often used for superficial tumors due to their relatively low penetration depth.

 

Option B. Protons are highly ionizing and are utilized in proton therapy due to their unique depth-dose distribution characterized by the Bragg peak, which allows for high dose delivery to the target with sparing of surrounding tissue.

 

Option D. Gamma-photons are high-energy electromagnetic radiation that can penetrate deeply into tissues and are widely used in external beam radiation therapy. Their ionization potential is less than particles such as protons and helium ions, but they can cover a larger volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Helium ions, or alpha particles, have the highest ionization potential, which translates to a high level of biological damage per unit of path traveled within tissue.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: During a medical review session discussing oncology treatments, the instructor asks the residents to identify the cell cycle phase that demonstrates the highest sensitivity to ionizing radiation, which is a key consideration when planning radiation therapy for cancer patients. Which phase should be considered the target for maximum radiation-induced damage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. G2M

 

Option A:

 

The most radiosensitive phase of cell cycle is G2M.

The least radiosensitive phase is the late S phase.

 

G2/M phase - Cells are most radiosensitive during the G2/M phase because this is the period of cell division where DNA is most vulnerable and cells are unable to repair the DNA damage effectively before mitosis

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. M phase - Although the M phase is where actual cell division occurs, it is not as radiosensitive as the G2/M phase. However, it is still more sensitive compared to other phases due to active mitotic processes.

 

Option C. G1 phase - This phase is before DNA synthesis. Cells in the G1 phase have a moderate level of radiosensitivity as the cellular repair mechanisms are still relatively active.

 

Option D. S phase - The S phase involves DNA replication. Cells are the least radiosensitive during the late S phase because the DNA double-strand break repair mechanisms are most active.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The G2/M phase is considered the most radiosensitive due to the reduced capacity for DNA repair before cell division, making it the optimal phase for radiotherapy targeting. Conversely, the late S phase is the least sensitive as cells are actively engaged in DNA synthesis and repair, which can mitigate radiation damage.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radioprotector?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Oxygen

 

Option C:

 

Oxygen is a Radiosensitizer.

 

Oxygen: Oxygen is actually a radiosensitizer, not a radioprotector. The presence of oxygen can increase the effectiveness of radiation therapy by generating oxygen radicals that cause DNA damage in cancer cells. This is known as the oxygen effect.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Zinc Oxide: Although not a typical radioprotector used systemically for patients undergoing radiation therapy, zinc oxide is often found in topical formulations and may have protective effects against skin irritation caused by radiation exposure. It's more commonly associated with skin protection in the form of physical barrier sunscreens.

 

Option B. Pentoxyphylline: This is a methylxanthine derivative that has been used to improve blood flow and oxygenation to tissues, potentially mitigating the effects of radiation-induced damage. However, its primary use is not as a radioprotector in the clinical setting.

 

Option D. Amifostine: This is a well-known radioprotector. Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent used in clinical settings to reduce the risk of radiation-induced xerostomia in patients undergoing radiation therapy for head and neck cancer, and it may also protect against other radiation-induced injuries.

 

Educational objective :

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: As a radiation oncology resident, you are discussing the potential harmful effects of radiation with a patient. Which of the following is a non-deterministic effect of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mutations

 

Option D:

 

Mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

Mutations: These are non-deterministic effects, meaning they can occur without a threshold level of radiation, and their probability (not severity) increases with the dose. Mutations are random alterations in the DNA that can lead to cancer or hereditary effects

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Burns: These are deterministic effects, meaning they have a threshold level of radiation dose below which they do not occur and above which the severity increases with the dose.

 

Option B. Cataracts: The formation of cataracts is generally a deterministic effect of radiation, where there is a threshold dose, and the severity of the cataract increases with increasing radiation dose.

 

Option C. Hair loss: This is typically a deterministic effect that occurs above a certain threshold of radiation to the scalp and is often temporary, with the severity depending on the radiation dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations are a stochastic effect of radiation exposure, occurring without a threshold and having a probability that increases with radiation dose, which can lead to oncogenic transformation or hereditary changes.

 

Effects of radiation

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of progressively worsening pain and swelling in his right leg for the past few weeks. On physical examination, there is tenderness, swelling, and warmth over the distal femur, and he has limited range of motion in his knee. Imaging studies, including X-rays and MRI, show evidence of a lytic lesion in the bone with surrounding soft tissue mass. The oncologist suggests radiotherapy for the tumor. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma 

 

Option A:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma is the most radiosensitive bone tumor.

 

Ewing Sarcoma: Typically presents during adolescence and is characterized by localized pain and swelling. Radiographic findings often show a lytic bone lesion with a "layered" periosteal reaction, sometimes described as an "onion skin" appearance. Ewing sarcoma is known for its radiosensitivity, making it a likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Melanoma: It is not typically associated with a presentation of bone pain or a lytic lesion in a teenager, making this option less likely.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: While osteosarcoma is treated with radiotherapy, it's less radiosensitive compared to Ewing sarcoma.

 

Option D. Pancreatic Carcinoma: This is an extremely unlikely diagnosis in a 15-year-old presenting with a bone lesion. Pancreatic carcinoma is a gastrointestinal tumor that would not present as a primary bone lesion in the leg and is more common in older adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When presented with an adolescent patient who exhibits a lytic bone lesion and a periosteal soft tissue mass, Ewing sarcoma should be considered as a potential diagnosis. This condition is notable for its radiosensitivity.

 

Radiosensitivity of tumors:

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 588

questions.text: A pediatric patient presents with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, including morning headaches and vomiting. MRI of the brain reveals a posterior fossa tumor. The treatment plan includes surgical resection followed by adjuvant therapy. Which of the following tumors most commonly warrants postoperative craniospinal irradiation due to its high propensity for metastasis along the neuraxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Medulloblastoma

 

Option D:

 

Medulloblastoma is treated with craniospinal irradiation. It is a radiosensitive tumor that responds very well to radiotherapy.

 

Medulloblastoma: This highly malignant primary brain tumor is most common in children and is known for its potential to disseminate through cerebrospinal fluid. Craniospinal irradiation is a standard component of adjuvant therapy following surgical resection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oligodendroglioma: A type of glioma that often presents in adults. It typically does not metastasize along the craniospinal axis, so craniospinal irradiation is not standard treatment.

 

Option B. Pilocytic Astrocytoma: This tumor is usually benign with a low propensity for metastasis. Treatment mainly involves surgical resection, and craniospinal irradiation is not commonly indicated.

 

Option C. Mixed Oligoastrocytoma: Similar to oligodendrogliomas, these mixed gliomas do not frequently metastasize along the neuraxis. Hence, they usually do not require craniospinal irradiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniospinal irradiation is typically indicated in the treatment of medulloblastoma due to the tumor's high risk of neuraxis metastasis. This approach is part of a multimodal therapy that includes surgical resection and chemotherapy, aiming to manage both the primary tumor and prevent or treat any metastatic spread.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 726

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker presents with a persistent cough and increasing shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Imaging studies, including a chest X-ray and CT scan, reveal a large mass in the right lung and lymph node involvement. Biopsy of the lung mass reveals small, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm and a high mitotic rate. Immunohistochemical studies show positive staining for markers including chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56, consistent with small cell lung carcinoma. He is posted for thoracic external beam radiotherapy. How will the respiratory movement be counteracted during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Gating

 

Option B:

 

The respiratory movement of a patient with inoperable small cell lung carcinoma during thoracic external beam radiotherapy can be counteracted using a technique called gating.

 

Gating synchronizes radiation delivery with the patient's respiratory cycle, minimizing exposure to healthy tissue and ensuring the radiation is delivered when the tumor is in the targeted location.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Arc Modulation: This technique allows for the radiation dose to be delivered from multiple angles around the patient, which can improve dose distribution but does not specifically address respiratory motion.

 

Option C. Fractionation: This refers to splitting the total dose of radiation into multiple smaller doses, which allows healthy tissue to repair between sessions, but it does not account for tumor movement during treatment.

 

Option D. After-Loading: This term is typically associated with brachytherapy, where radioactive sources are placed within or near the tumor site after the patient is positioned, not directly related to respiratory motion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The role of gating in thoracic external beam radiotherapy for lung cancer, is designed to counteract tumor movement due to respiration, thereby maximizing dose to the tumor while minimizing exposure to healthy surrounding tissues.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 718

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and is started on chemotherapy as part of their treatment. During the course of their chemotherapy, the child develops central nervous system (CNS) involvement with ALL, which requires additional treatment with radiation therapy. The child undergoes cranial irradiation to prevent CNS relapse and reduce the risk of leukemia cells spreading to the brain and spinal cord. The radiation therapy is administered in a series of daily treatments over several weeks. Which of the following is affected least by the radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Neurons

 

Option C:

 

Neurons: Neurons are well-differentiated and quiescent, meaning they do not divide, making them less sensitive to radiation compared to other rapidly dividing cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spermatogonia: These are undifferentiated, rapidly-dividing cells and are highly sensitive to radiation, potentially leading to infertility.

 

Option B. Intestinal epithelial cells: These cells are also rapidly dividing and very sensitive to radiation, which can cause gastrointestinal side effects.

 

Option D. Bone marrow: Contains rapidly dividing hematopoietic stem cells, making it very sensitive to radiation, which can lead to bone marrow suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurons, due to their well-differentiated and non-dividing nature, are the least sensitive to radiation therapy compared to other rapidly dividing cell types, such as spermatogonia, intestinal epithelial cells, and bone marrow cells.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

choices.text: Damage to nearby structures is significant

questions.text: All are true about stereotactic radio surgery except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Damage to nearby structures is significant

 

Option D:

 

Damage to nearby structures is significant: Incorrect. One of the main advantages of SRS is its ability to deliver high doses of radiation to the target while minimizing the damage to surrounding structures due to its precision.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gamma-rays are used: This is true. Gamma Knife, one form of SRS, uses gamma rays from Cobalt-60 sources to target brain lesions with precision.

 

Option B. High-dose focused Radiotherapy is delivered: Correct. SRS delivers a high dose of radiation in a single session, focused precisely on the target area, minimizing exposure to surrounding healthy tissue.

 

Option C. Used in AV malformation: True. SRS is used in the non-invasive treatment of arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), among other conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stereotactic radiosurgery is designed to deliver focused high-dose radiation to the target lesion with minimal damage to the surrounding structures.

 

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is Gamma Knife surgery NOT typically indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Disseminated tuberculomas

 

Option C:

 

Disseminated tuberculomas: Gamma Knife surgery is not commonly used for disseminated tuberculomas, as they are typically treated with anti-tuberculous medications rather than radiation therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acoustic neuroma: Gamma Knife surgery is frequently used for treating acoustic neuromas (vestibular schwannomas) due to its precise delivery of radiation that can target the tumor without damaging nearby structures like the facial nerve.

 

Option B. Pituitary adenoma: Gamma Knife surgery is a treatment option for non-functional pituitary adenomas, especially when surgical resection is not possible or the tumor recurs after surgery.

 

Option D. Trigeminal Neuralgia: Gamma Knife surgery is used as a non-invasive treatment option for refractory trigeminal neuralgia that does not respond to medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gamma Knife surgery is used for various intracranial pathologies where precise radiation is needed without surgical intervention. It is not indicated for disseminated tuberculomas, which are generally treated with medical therapy.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: In assessing radioisotope therapy options for a patient with bone metastases, understanding the type of emissions from therapeutic radioisotopes is essential for appropriate treatment planning. Which of the following radioisotopes is a mixed beta/gamma emitter and is commonly used in the palliative treatment of painful bone metastases?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Samarium-153

 

Option D:

 

Samarium-153 and Rhenium-186 are mixed Beta/Gamma emitters.

Pure beta emitters release beta particles as their primary mode of decay.

Samarium-153 - This is the correct answer. Samarium-153 emits both beta and gamma radiation and is used for the palliative treatment of painful bone metastases, especially in cases of osteoblastic lesions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Yttrium-90 - A pure beta emitter used in radioembolization for liver tumors and in synovectomy procedures for rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B. Cobalt - Cobalt-60 is not a pure beta emitter; it primarily emits gamma rays and is used in external beam radiotherapy machines and in some forms of brachytherapy.

 

Option C. Strontium-90 - A pure beta emitter used in radiotherapy, particularly for eye conditions such as pterygium, and is also involved in bone-seeking radiopharmaceuticals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Samarium-153 is a mixed beta/gamma emitter used in palliative treatment for painful bone metastases, and to differentiate it from other radioisotopes which are pure beta emitters or have different clinical uses.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with new-onset seizures and a recent MRI showing a single 2 cm enhancing lesion in the right cerebral cortex. She has a history of breast cancer treated 2 years ago. Based on the patient's history and current presentation, Stereotactic radiosurgery is used for treatment of?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Brain tumor

 

Option A:

 

Stereotactic radiosurgery is a non-invasive treatment option for brain tumors, especially for patients with a single or a small number of metastatic lesions, who have already undergone cancer treatment elsewhere in the body.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lung carcinoma - While primary lung tumors can metastasize to the brain, stereotactic radiosurgery is typically not the primary treatment modality for the lung carcinoma itself but may be considered for isolated brain metastases.

 

Option C. Cervical cancer - Treatment for cervical cancer primarily includes surgery, chemotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy. Stereotactic radiosurgery is not a standard treatment for cervical cancer.

 

Option D. Renal carcinoma - Similar to lung carcinoma, stereotactic radiosurgery may be utilized for brain metastases secondary to renal carcinoma, but it is not used for treating the primary kidney tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The goal is to recognize that stereotactic radiosurgery is most appropriately used for treating brain tumors, including metastases to the brain from other primary cancers. This treatment modality allows for precise targeting of the tumor with minimal damage to surrounding brain tissue, which is critical in the delicate neural environment.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 716

choices.text: Carcinoma base of tongue with positive lymph nodes

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with a non-productive cough and a solitary pulmonary nodule on chest imaging. Biopsy confirms stage 1 non-small cell lung carcinoma. Given the patient's significant cardiac comorbidities making him a poor surgical candidate, Stereotactic Radiotherapy is used in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stage 1 Lung Carcinoma

 

Option B:

 

Stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT), also known as stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR), is an effective non-invasive treatment for patients with early-stage non-small cell lung cancer, especially for those who are not surgical candidates.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Miliary Tuberculosis - Incorrect. Stereotactic radiotherapy is not used in the treatment of miliary tuberculosis, which typically requires anti-tubercular drugs.

 

Option C. Lymphangitis Carcinomatosis - Incorrect. This condition represents diffuse spread of malignancy and is not typically treated with localized therapy like stereotactic radiotherapy.

 

Option D. Carcinoma Base of Tongue with Positive Nodes - Incorrect. Stereotactic radiotherapy is usually not the primary treatment for head and neck cancers, especially when lymph nodes are involved, due to the complex anatomy and the need for comprehensive regional control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SBRT is a precise and intense form of radiation therapy that's used to treat small, well-defined tumors in inoperable patients, particularly in cases of early-stage lung cancer. It's an effective alternative when surgery is contraindicated due to comorbid conditions.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 74

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with no known health conditions presents to the emergency department after experiencing severe abdominal pain for 12 hours. She has no prior imaging studies available and requires a diagnostic test that can provide detailed information but is concerned about radiation exposure. Which of the following imaging studies exposes the patient to the highest level of ionizing radiation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. CT scan

 

Option C:

 

CT scans provide detailed images of internal structures and are valuable in diagnosing a range of conditions but generally expose the patient to higher levels of ionizing radiation compared to other imaging modalities listed.

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. Bone Scan - Incorrect. While a bone scan does involve exposure to radioactive material, the total body radiation dose is generally less than that received from a CT scan of the abdomen.

 

Option B. X-ray - Incorrect. A conventional X-ray of the abdomen exposes a patient to radiation, but the dose is significantly lower than that of a CT scan of the same region.

 

Option D. MRI - Incorrect. MRI does not use ionizing radiation. Instead, it uses a magnetic field and radio waves to produce images and is considered a safer alternative in terms of radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scans, especially of the abdomen, are associated with a higher dose of radiation compared to X-rays, bone scans, and MRI, which does not involve ionizing radiation.

 

Radiation exposure:

 

CT Abdomen: - 500 Chest X-rays (highest)
CT Head: - 100-150 Chest X-rays
Mammography: – 20-25 Chest X-rays

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition
